asset.about: Paramedics performed CPR on the man, but he could not be saved.
asset.body:
A major police operation was sparked and ferries were cancelled after a man drowned in Sydney Harbour on Thursday morning.

A police spokeswoman said the man went overboard on a Sydney ferry near Manly just after 7.30am, and his body was recovered from the water shortly after.

Ferries between Rose Bay and Pyrmont were cancelled due to the police operation.

An ambulance spokesman said paramedics performed CPR, but the man could not be saved.

The police spokeswoman said the man's death was not being treated as suspicious.

Lifeline 13 11 14

Mensline 1300 789 978

beyondblue 1300 224 636

headlines.headline: Police operation sparked after man goes overboard on Sydney ferry

authors.bio: Rachel Clun is a reporter at the Sydney Morning Herald. She was previously a reporter with the Brisbane Times and Domain.

seo.title: Manly Ferry: Police operation sparked after man goes overboard and dies

asset.about: The tourism industry has offered strong support for a proposed 237-metre hotel and residential tower on The Star casino site, but not everyone is convinced of its benefits.
asset.body:
The Star is gambling on attracting wealthy Chinese tourists to a $500 million hotel and residential tower on its casino site in Pyrmont.

The will house a luxury 220-room Ritz Carlton hotel and 204 residential apartments, which “could join the short-term accommodation supply”, according to a spokesman for The Star.

The 237-metre tower will also feature a neighbourhood centre that could include a social enterprise cafe, library and function spaces.

“The location and the community have been considered throughout the process,” the spokesman said. “This development will also provide significant economic benefits for Pyrmont, Sydney and NSW.”

Yet the development, which also promises public transport upgrades and a renovation of The Star's facilities, has divided opinion.

Patricia Forsythe, the executive director of the Sydney Business Chamber, said the city had to create “iconic” buildings and “the proposed development hits the mark”.

"Sydney’s economy is anchored in the service economy and we cannot be half-hearted about development," she said.

Ms Forsythe said the area was becoming a major tourism and entertainment hub for Sydney "and that means people and activity in the precinct day and night".

"Whilst that will have local impact, it also means great choice for locals in terms of restaurants, places to visit, and job opportunity," she said.

But Alex Greenwich, the independent member for Sydney, condemned the tower as “inappropriate and destructive”.

“The proposed development breaches height, floor space and zoning restrictions; it fails to represent any strategic planning for the region and has no planning merit,” he wrote in a letter to the NSW Planning Minister Anthony Roberts.

Mr Greenwich said the tower would be an “aesthetic disgrace” and create “serious impacts” on nearby communities.

“There is no need for The Star casino to build such a tower on the site, particularly given it would include residential purposes which have no connection to the facility’s core purpose,” he said.

Elizabeth Elenius, the convenor of Pyrmont Action, said the community group strongly opposed the proposed tower because of its excessive height.

She suggested the tower could detrimentally affect residents by worsening traffic congestion, overshadowing, causing reflective glare on some dwellings and obscuring views.

But Ms Elenius said the neighbourhood centre, if accessible and affordable, may alleviate the suburb’s lack of community facilities.

“The proposal will enable The Star to compete with the Crown development,” she said. “It will create employment, and no doubt money will be generated for the government.”

Mr Greenwich said the tower would spoil the skyline from multiple vantage points and “suffocate” important public spaces, “The proposed development will result in substantial destruction of private views to a large number of homes in Pyrmont," he said.

He also expressed concern about traffic congestion and the potential of the tower to cast a shadow over parts of Pyrmont such as Union Square and Pyrmont Bay Park.

The Star’s proposal will be determined by the Independent Planning Commission because more than 25 submissions opposing the tower had been received by the NSW Department of Planning and Environment.

“It is legally obliged to assess any application submitted and it is being assessed on its merits,” a DPE spokesman said. “All submissions relating to the height of the proposal will be seriously considered.”

However, Ms Elenius criticised the planning system, which she said permitted developments in a “rules-free” environment.

“Successive governments have whittled away most constraints by declaring sites as of state significance or other descriptors, which are able to be planned in a similarly rules-free environment,” she wrote in a letter to the DPE.

“But to propose that Pyrmont will ‘transition’ to such a rules-free planning environment that will allow 60-storey towers anywhere in the peninsula is beyond alarming.”

The City of Sydney declined to comment on the proposal before submissions closing on October 9.

But a spokeswoman for Sydney’s lord mayor Clover Moore said: “The lord mayor is concerned about the proposal and has asked for an urgent briefing.”

In contrast, Liberal councillor Christine Forster said: “The Star’s proposed Ritz Carlton development would be an elegant addition to the city’s burgeoning skyline and will play an important role in our future visitor economy.”

The Star Sydney lacked high-end hotels to cater for a forecast increase in tourist numbers, which, it said, were “led by the rapidly expanding wealthy Chinese middle-class demographic”.

Margy Osmond, the chief executive of the Tourism & Transport Forum, said the tower had the potential to transform the “wider West Harbour precinct” into Sydney’s tourism and entertainment hub.

Ms Osmond said the tower would deliver benefits to local residents including “better connectivity to the light rail and a focus on reducing traffic around the precinct”.

data.quote: The proposed development hits the mark.

data.caption: The convenor of Pyrmont Action, Elizabeth Elenius, pictured with Guy Di Benedetto, said the community group strongly opposed the proposed tower because of its excessive height.
An artist's impression of a 237-metre hotel and residential tower proposed for The Star casino site in Pyrmont.

data.quoteByline: Alex Greenwich, independent member for Sydney

headlines.headline: 'Aesthetic disgrace': Proposed tower on casino site divides opinion

authors.bio: Andrew Taylor is a Senior Reporter for The Sydney Morning Herald.
authors.name: Andrew Taylor
authors.title: Senior Reporter

asset.about: The City of Sydney could raise up to $200 million in funds for its $1.7 billion capital works program with the sale of a former depot at Pyrmont
asset.body:
The City of Sydney could raise up to $200 million in funds for its $1.7 billion capital works program with the sale of a former council depot at Pyrmont, on the city fringe, which is capable of supporting a landmark mixed-use development project.

According to the council, the sale of the 1.2ha site will help deliver a new childcare centre and multi-use indoor recreational centre for the local community, while allowing for a significant mixed-use project, subject to the relevant planning approvals.

CBRE’s Scott Gray-Spencer and Kelwyn Teo will manage the sale of the 14-26 Wattle Street property, which is tipped to generate significant interest from major Australian developers and offshore groups.

The planning framework provides for more than 50,000 square metres of mixed-used floor space, including a 91-place childcare centre and a multi-use indoor recreational centre, ownership of which will be transferred back to the City of Sydney.

Lord Mayor Clover Moore said the sale would help create much-needed public facilities for the area’s growing population.

''Selling land surplus to requirements will help the City respond to the growing recreation and daycare needs generated by high-density residential developments and the expanding Ultimo Public School,'' the she said.

Mr Gray-Spencer said the property’s location, near the soon-to-be revamped Sydney Fish Market, the harbour foreshore and Wentworth Park and on the doorstep of the light rail, ''would help generate strong buyer interest, providing an opportunity to secure significant, infill development opportunity''.

''Through the sale structure, the successful purchaser will have the opportunity to secure development approval prior to settlement, substantially de-risking the project,'' Mr Gray-Spencer said.

''From a residential perspective, the site benefits from its proximity to the CBD, Broadway Shopping Centre and Central Park, as well as direct connectivity to Sydney’s major universities including the University of Technology Sydney and the University of New South Wales via the light rail.''

The site is also located in what is becoming Sydney's technology and media hub, joining the likes of Google, Domain, Fairfax Media, the publisher of the Sydney Morning Herald, and television stations Ten, the ABC and Seven.

There is also a significant upgrade underway of the Darling Harbour precinct with two new hotels, The W and Ritz-Carlton at The Star, a revamped Harbourside shopping centre and a potential new light rail train station at Cockle Bay.

''These new facilities will help meet growing demand and are designed to work within parking and traffic in the area,'' Ms Moore said.

The site was previously proposed as the location for a new Ultimo Public School and childcare centre but the NSW Department of Education advised the City in 2015 it would not proceed with the purchase.

The City’s Open Space, Sport and Recreation Needs Study, adopted in late 2016, recommended more indoor multi-purpose courts for inner-city areas, including Pyrmont.

data.caption: The former City of Sydney council depot at 14-26 Wattle Street, Pyrmont.

headlines.headline: Pyrmont depot could reap $200m for City council

authors.bio: Carolyn Cummins is Commercial Property Editor for The Sydney Morning Herald.

asset.about: Sydney's biggest bird nest, the Kengo Kuma and Associates-designed Darling Square, is being sold by the developer Lendlease with a price tag of about $70 million.
asset.body:
Sydney's biggest bird nest, the Kengo Kuma and Associates-designed The Exchange in Darling Square, is being sold by the developer Lendlease with a price tag of about $70 million.

Sitting on the site of the former Sydney Entertainment Centre, at the southern end of Darling Park, it is the new home for the City of Sydney, run by lord mayor Clover Moore, a library and an innovation hub to develop start-ups.

Looking like a beehive or a bird's nest, it is the centrepiece of Darling Square, which sits at the heart of the NSW government’s $3.4 billion transformation of Darling Harbour.

It comes as major business groups operating in the precinct - including The Star Entertainment, Google, AccorHotels, Crown resorts, AMP and GPT Group, among others - has formed the Western Harbour working group to create a metro station for the area.

The potential of the ''Western Harbour'' precinct, broadly comprising Barangaroo, Darling Harbour, Pyrmont/Ultimo and adjacent areas, has been recognised for a number of years.

PwC estimates conservatively that the incremental economic output of this precinct will be more than $20 billion over the first 10 years, and that it will be NSW's second-largest economy behind the CBD.

There are also two hotels being constructed at Darling Harbour, the W Hotel on the site of the former Imax theatre and a Ritz-Carlton adjoining the Star casino.

Benefiting from the revamp of the area is the distinctive Exchange building, which will also include market halls, a childcare centre and roof-top restaurant and bar. It will be clad in curved Accoya-processed wood, made from NZ-grown radiata pine and prepared at St Peters-based Normoyle Engineering.

Nearly three-quarters of the estimated 20 kilometres of timber will be attached to the building in prefabricated panels, while the rest will be wrapped around it, ribbon-like.

The six-storey civic building was approved by the NSW Planning Minister Anthony Roberts in May 2017. Upon completion, Darling Square will include 1500 residential units, 26,000 square metres of commercial office space, 12,000 sqm of retail, community and leisure uses, 1300-bed student accommodation and the now-open 590-room luxury hotel, the Sofitel.

John Burton, managing director, urban regeneration at Lendlease, said The Exchange was a distinctive addition to
Sydney’s skyline.

''Darling Square is building on the revitalised energy of Darling Harbour by combining commercial, retail, residential with public open spaces. Urban regeneration projects like Darling Square are key to relieving some of the pressure on our cities by creating new and thriving neighbourhoods,'' Mr Burton said.

Advising on the sale, James Parry, director, CBRE, said overseas and Australian investors were expected to show an interest in the property.

''The Exchange represents a fantastic opportunity to invest in a mixed-use building at the centrepiece of a new urban neighbourhood – Darling Square,'' Mr Parry said.

''With a range of key tenants already in place, The Exchange is set to become an important part of the city’s fabric, bringing food, learning and community together in a unique architectural form.''

data.caption: The roof-top bar at The Exchange building, Darling Square.
The Exchange, a mixed-use building at the heart of Lendlease’s Darling Square precinct designed by Japanese architecture firm Kengo Kuma and Associates.

headlines.headline: Sydney's Darling Square bird nest has $70m-plus price tag

authors.bio: Carolyn Cummins is Commercial Property Editor for The Sydney Morning Herald.

asset.about: A man has been charged after he allegedly jumped off a crane in Darling Harbour and parachuted over traffic early on Tuesday morning.
asset.body:
A French BASE jumper has been arrested after he allegedly jumped off a crane in Darling Harbour and parachuted over traffic early Tuesday morning.

It is alleged 24-year-old Jonathan Perherin broke into a construction site on Wheat Road in the city about 3.15am.

Mr Perherin then allegedly climbed to the top of a crane with BASE jumping equipment and a recording device, before leaping off the building.

Police believe he then parachuted over several lanes of traffic and Darling Harbour, before landing on Darling Drive in Pyrmont.

The French national was caught by Darling Harbour council rangers before he was handed over to police.

He was charged with entering enclosed land and risking the safety of others by abseiling off a building.

Granted conditional bail, Mr Perherin will appear at Downing Centre Local Court on October 17.

Mr Perherin has been in Sydney since early September and seen a number of famous sites around the city including Bondi Beach and the Royal National Park.

The self-described adrenaline addict uploaded a video to his Facebook page in July of a nighttime BASE jump he did off a crane in Montpellier in the south of France.

In the video, he can be seen sitting on the crane before jumping and activating his parachute. He lands on a road, and quickly gathers his parachute before a car drives past.

When asked if it was illegal to BASE jump in NSW, the attorney-general's office pointed to the Summary Offences Act which states: "A person who risks the safety of any other person as a consequence of abseiling, jumping or parachuting from any part of a building or other structure, is guilty of an offence."

Australian BASE Association president Gary Cunningham says while it's important thrillseekers respect the law advocates are "disappointed" it's so difficult to get permission to BASE jump here.

"It occasionally leads to people doing jumps like the one this morning," he said in a statement to AAP.

Mr Cunningham, who is an experienced BASE jumper, says the very real risks associated with the sport mean participants need regular practice to maintain their skills.

He's called on authorities to open up more areas where people can jump safely.

"Most people only get four weeks holiday per year to travel overseas to places where they can legally jump," he said.

"Not being able to practice for the rest of the year just leads to a decay in our skills and knowledge and makes it more dangerous than it should be."

data.caption: Mr Perherin has been in Australia taking in the sights since early September.

headlines.headline: Man charged after allegedly parachuting over Darling Harbour

authors.bio: Rachel Clun is a reporter at the Sydney Morning Herald. She was previously a reporter with the Brisbane Times and Domain.
authors.name: Rachel Clun
authors.title: Reporter

seo.description: The man's arrest comes just days before the World Parachuting Championships kick off in Queensland.
seo.title: Darling Harbour: French BASE jumper arrested after allegedly parachuting over Sydney
